title: Kawasaki Disease Diagnostic Criteria
description: Diagnoses Kawasaki Disease using fever duration and principal clinical features. Kawasaki disease is a systemic vasculitis of childhood that can cause coronary artery aneurysms if untreated. Diagnosis requires fever ≥4 days plus ≥4 of 5 principal clinical features, or fever ≥5 days plus 2-3 features (incomplete Kawasaki).

parameters.name: fever_duration
parameters.description: Duration of fever in days. Minimum 4 days required for diagnosis consideration

parameters.name: bilateral_conjunctival_injection
parameters.description: Bilateral conjunctival injection without exudate - Principal clinical feature

parameters.name: oral_changes
parameters.description: Oral changes including cracked and erythematous lips, strawberry tongue, or erythema of oral mucosa - Principal clinical feature

parameters.name: cervical_lymphadenopathy
parameters.description: Cervical lymphadenopathy (≥1.5 cm diameter), usually unilateral - Principal clinical feature

parameters.name: extremity_changes
parameters.description: Extremity changes including erythema of palms/soles, induration of hands/feet, or desquamation of fingertips - Principal clinical feature

parameters.name: polymorphous_rash
parameters.description: Polymorphous rash (not vesicular or bullous) - Principal clinical feature

result.name: diagnosis
result.description: Kawasaki disease diagnosis based on fever duration and principal clinical features

formula: Classic KD: Fever ≥4 days + ≥4 of 5 principal features. Incomplete KD: Fever ≥5 days + 2-3 principal features with supportive laboratory findings or coronary abnormalities
notes: Classic Kawasaki disease: fever ≥4 days plus ≥4 of 5 principal clinical features
Incomplete Kawasaki disease: fever ≥5 days plus 2-3 principal features (more common in infants <6 months)
Principal features may not appear simultaneously and can resolve before diagnosis
Early diagnosis and treatment (within 10 days of fever onset) reduces risk of coronary artery abnormalities
Infants ≤6 months are at highest risk for incomplete presentation and coronary complications
IVIG (intravenous immunoglobulin) plus aspirin is first-line treatment
Follow-up echocardiography is essential to monitor for coronary artery changes
Second-line treatments for IVIG-resistant cases include infliximab, corticosteroids, or cyclosporine
